awd_titl_txt: Rural Gateways:  Fostering the Development of Rural Librarians as Informal Science Facilitators
awd_abstract_narration:
Due to geographical isolation, rural communities are often underserved by the informal STEM (science, technology, engineering, and mathematics) education system.  As part of its overall strategy to enhance learning in informal environments, the Advancing Informal STEM Learning (AISL) program funds innovative resources for use in a variety of settings including rural communities. Thus, this project will help to develop rural libraries and librarians into STEM learning centers and facilitators who will use community assets providing new horizons for youth on career choices and adults on an enhanced STEM knowledge base. Through online professional development exercises, the library staff will enhance their knowledge, enabling them to develop and support new STEM learning mechanisms in their communities.

In this project, 110 rural libraries will be chosen from applicants to obtain advanced knowledge of how to facilitate STEM learning. It is anticipated that the staff will change from being resource persons to facilitators of STEM knowledge transfer. The project is a collaboration between Dartmouth College, Dominican University, the Institute of Learning Innovation, Dawson, Media Group, and the Califa Group. The research questions address: a quantitative assessment of rural librarian's STEM efficacy and professional identity, and a determination of the efficacy and impact of multiple forms of professional development and learning tools on rural librarians' ability to participate in and facilitate informal STEM learning.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
RURAL GATEWAYS: Fostering the Development of Rural Librarians as Informal Science Facilitators is an Innovations in Development Project. It develops, tests, revises, and ultimately deploys an innovative model for sustainable, scalable, capacity-building in underserved rural communities, cultivating librarians as facilitators of informal science learning.


As a project in NSF-DRL, the intellectual merits of the project speak to the understandings achieved in cultivating self-efficacy among this group of librarians, through a scaffolded set of professional development activities, as well as materials developed and made accessible to the community of library professionals. To that end, a collection of materials consisting of professional development tools (available at https://my.nicheacademy.com/infopeople/course/18587) was developed as well as materials for hosting science learning events for the public (available at https://www.pushingthelimits.org/). In a broad study involving approximately 150 small and rural public libraries and their librarians, it was established that the materials were effective in giving librarians the skills and self-efficacy, and confidence to think of themselves as science-event conveners. Following recommendations from the participants, in order to broaden the reach of the project, all videos were translated into Spanish, additional thematically aligned books in Spanish were also added. In addition, another Unit (Pushing the Limits of Persistence) was created entirely in Spanish, with books and discussion questions. All the videos, book choices, discussion questions and marketing materials were moved to an open access public facing website (PushingTheLimits.org) and announcements have been made to libraries across the US through organizations including Makers In the Library, and the STAR Library Network STEM Resource Clearninghouse. The professional development materials for librarians have been published for free use via Niche Academy/InfoPeople, a highly regarded access point for librarian PD. Two journal articles were published and a third is anticipated. With this enhanced skill set, librarians and libraries may now be thought of as another venue for providing access to informal science learning for the public, thus helping to broaden access to scientific ideas in areas (small and rural towns) that are traditionally underserved in terms of access to informal science programming.


Last Modified: 02/01/2024
Modified by: Daniel N Rockmore
